articles.author: ELLEN KNICKMEYER and JENNIFER PELTZ
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — The suspected architect of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks and his fellow defendants may never face the death penalty under plea agreements now under consideration to bring an end to their more than decadelong prosecution, the Pentagon and FBI have advised families of some of the thousands killed.
articles.title: Plea negotiations could mean no 9/11 defendants face the death penalty, the US tells families

articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN, MARY KATHERINE WILDEMAN and BOBBY CAINA CALVAN
articles.description: KIHEI, Hawaii (AP) — Hurricane-fueled flash floods and mudslides. Lava that creeps into neighborhoods. Fierce drought that materializes in a flash and lingers. Earthquakes. And now, deadly fires that burn block after historic block.
articles.title: Fires and others disasters are increasing in Hawaii, according to this AP data analysis

articles.author: CLAIRE RUSH, JENNIFER SINCO KELLEHER and CHRISTOPHER WEBER
articles.description: LAHAINA, Hawaii (AP) — Public schools on Maui have started the process of reopening in a sign of recovery a week after wildfires demolished a historic town and killed over 100 people, even as additional cadaver dogs arrived Wednesday to help teams search for more remains on Hawaii's second-largest island.
articles.title: More cadaver dogs arrive to assist in search for bodies after wildfires kill at least 106 on Maui

articles.author: KATE BRUMBACK
articles.description: ATLANTA (AP) — The prosecutor in Atlanta who obtained an indictment this week against former President Donald Trump and 18 others wants to take the case to trial in March.
articles.title: Georgia prosecutor seeks March trial date for Trump and 18 others in election case

articles.author: LINLEY SANDERS and JONATHAN J. COOPER
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — Americans are deeply divided along party lines in their views of President Donald Trump's actions in the most recent criminal cases brought against him, a new poll shows, with about half saying his alleged attempt to interfere in Georgia's 2020 vote count was illegal.
articles.title: Americans are divided along party lines over Trump’s actions in election cases, AP-NORC poll shows

articles.author: LAURAN NEERGAARD
articles.description: NEW YORK (AP) — Surgeons transplanted a pig’s kidney into a brain-dead man and for over a month it's worked normally — a critical step toward an operation the New York team hopes to eventually try in living patients.
articles.title: Pig kidney works in a donated body for over a month, a step toward animal-human transplants

articles.author: KEVIN McGILL
articles.description: NEW ORLEANS (AP) — New restrictions on access to a drug used in the most common form of abortion in the U.S. would be imposed under a federal appeals court ruling issued Wednesday, but the Supreme Court will have the final say.
articles.title: Some abortion drug restrictions are upheld by an appeals court in a case bound for the Supreme Court

articles.author: ELLEN KNICKMEYER and JENNIFER PELTZ
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — The suspected architect of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks and his fellow defendants may never face the death penalty under plea agreements now under consideration to bring an end to their more than decadelong prosecution, the Pentagon and FBI have advised families of some of the thousands killed.
articles.title: Plea negotiations could mean no 9/11 defendants face the death penalty, the US tells families

articles.author: JOHN HANNA and JIM SALTER
articles.description: MARION, Kansas (AP) — A Kansas prosecutor said Wednesday that he found insufficient evidence to support the police raid of a weekly newspaper and that all seized material should be returned in a dispute over press freedoms that the White House acknowledged it is watching closely.
articles.title: Kansas prosecutor says police should return computers and cellphones seized in raid on newspaper

articles.author: JAKE OFFENHARTZ
articles.description: NEW YORK (AP) — A former fundraiser for U.S. Rep. George Santos was indicted Wednesday on federal charges that he impersonated a high-ranking congressional aide while soliciting contributions for the New York Republican's campaign.
articles.title: A former fundraiser for Rep. George Santos has been charged with wire fraud and identity theft
